content: The verdicts in the [Beer Hall Putsch](/wiki/Beer_Hall_Putsch "Beer Hall Putsch") trial were announced. [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler"), [Ernst Pöhner](/wiki/Ernst_P%C3%B6hner "Ernst Pöhner"), [Hermann Kriebel](/wiki/Hermann_Kriebel "Hermann Kriebel") and [Friedrich Weber](/wiki/Friedrich_Weber_(veterinarian) "Friedrich Weber (veterinarian)") were all found guilty of treason and sentenced to five years in prison, with a chance of parole in six months. [Erich Ludendorff](/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff "Erich Ludendorff") was acquitted. Hitler was taken to [Landsberg Prison](/wiki/Landsberg_Prison "Landsberg Prison") and given a large and comfortable room with a fine view.

content: In the town of [Lilly, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Lilly,_Pennsylvania "Lilly, Pennsylvania"), members of the [Ku Klux Klan](/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan "Ku Klux Klan") shot 22 people, two of them fatally, firing randomly into a crowd at the town's railroad station. The shooting happened after some residents of the town "played a stream of water from the town fire hose upon the visitors as they were marching back to the station." An estimated 500 Klansmen had arrived, uninvited, to Lilly and held a ceremony at a nearby field, then marched in a procession to the train, which was taking them to nearby [Johnstown](/wiki/Johnstown,_Pennsylvania "Johnstown, Pennsylvania"). After the train arrived at Johnstown, the Klansmen were met by more than 50 police officers, who arrested 25 of the Klan members and confiscated fifty guns. Four additional people, residents of Lilly, were arrested the next day and the 29 were charged with murder.
sources: "Four Are Slain, 13 Shot During Visit of Klan— Residents of Pennsylvania Town Attacked After Using Hose". *[Baltimore Sun](/wiki/Baltimore_Sun "Baltimore Sun")*. April 6, 1924. p. 1.

The [Lista Nazionale](/wiki/National_List_(Italy) "National List (Italy)"), (a coalition headed by [National Fascist Party](/wiki/National_Fascist_Party "National Fascist Party") leader [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini"), received 65% of the votes and 374 of the seats in Parliament (74%) in accordance with the [Acerbo Law](/wiki/Acerbo_Law "Acerbo Law"), which provided that whatever party received more than 25% of the vote and the most votes overall would automatically be awarded two-thirds of the seats. The PPI party of [Alcide De Gasperi](/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi "Alcide De Gasperi"), who would become Prime Minister of Italy after World War II, received the second most votes (9%) and dropped from 108 seats to only 39.

content: The committee headed by [Charles G. Dawes](/wiki/Charles_G._Dawes "Charles G. Dawes") submitted its [plan](/wiki/Dawes_Plan "Dawes Plan") to reorganize the German economy and for the Allies to restructure the method of [reparations payments](/wiki/World_War_I_reparations "World War I reparations"). Among the changes were that while the Allies would retain military rights in occupied territory, Germany would retain control of its railways and industries, with some Allied supervision, and Germans would pay taxes similar to the rates of other nations. Payments would be adjusted upward or downward "according to an index of prosperity", with a neutral American observer being the judge of Germany's capacity to pay.
sources: "Experts Report on Reparation Payment Plans for Germany; Dawes Sees Peace, If Accepted; Military Control Left in Hands of Allies". *[Washington Evening Star](/wiki/Washington_Evening_Star "Washington Evening Star")*. April 9, 1924. p. 1.

["Chronology 1924"](https://web.archive.org/web/20200402163020/http://www.indiana.edu/~league/1924.htm). *indiana.edu*. 2002. Archived from [the original](http://www.indiana.edu/~league/1924.htm) on April 2, 2020. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: [Pope Pius XI](/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI "Pope Pius XI") abruptly canceled plans to become the first Roman Catholic Pontiff since (/wiki/1870 "1870") to travel outside of Vatican City. The Pope had been scheduled to one-half mile out of the walls of the Vatican and into [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome") in order to dedicate the new building for the [Knights of Columbus](/wiki/Knights_of_Columbus "Knights of Columbus"), but decided, after banner headlines in papers in Rome and around the world to remain "a voluntary prisoner" inside the Vatican. His decision came 30 minutes before he was due to arrive. Appearing in his place was the Papal Secretary of State, Cardinal Gasparri.
sources: "Pope, At Eleventh Hour, Drops Plan To Visit K. of C. Building". *[Baltimore Sun](/wiki/Baltimore_Sun "Baltimore Sun")*. April 10, 1924. p. 1.

content: The first large-scale train robbery in Greece took place shortly after 12 masked and armed bandits boarded a train at the [Doxaras railway station](/wiki/Doxaras_railway_station "Doxaras railway station") en route to Thessaloniki. Among the passengers were the Minister of Social Welfare and a former governor of Macedonia, and the bandits escaped with 400,000 [drachmas](/wiki/Modern_drachma "Modern drachma") of cash and valuables. The bandits apparently had been planning to board a train scheduled to carry Prime Minister Alexandros Papanastasiou, but Papanastasiou's train had not arrived at the time that the other train departed.

content: [Voting was held in Denmark](/wiki/1924_Danish_Folketing_election "1924 Danish Folketing election") for all 149 seats of the [Folketing](/wiki/Folketing "Folketing"), the European nation's unicameral parliament. [Thorvald Stauning](/wiki/Thorvald_Stauning "Thorvald Stauning")'s [Socialdemokratiet](/wiki/Social_Democrats_(Denmark) "Social Democrats (Denmark)") party won a plurality of the seats, gaining seven to change the balance of power from 51 to 48 for the liberal [Venstre](/wiki/Venstre_(Denmark) "Venstre (Denmark)") party (led by Prime Minister [Niels Neergaard](/wiki/Niels_Neergaard "Niels Neergaard"), to a 55 to 44 lead by the Social Democrats. Stauning would form a coalition government on April 23.

content: Japan's Ambassador to the United States, [Masanao Hanihara](/wiki/Masanao_Hanihara "Masanao Hanihara"), had a letter presented to U.S. Secretary of State [Charles Evans Hughes](/wiki/Charles_Evans_Hughes "Charles Evans Hughes"), warning him of "the grave consequences" that would come if the U.S. Senate followed the House of Representatives in passing the [Immigration Act of 1924](/wiki/Immigration_Act_of_1924 "Immigration Act of 1924"), specifically targeted against Asian nations, refusing to increase the quota of Japanese citizens who would be allowed to immigrate to the United States. Hughes transmitted the note to the Chairman of the Senate Immigration Committee, [LeBaron B. Colt](/wiki/LeBaron_B._Colt "LeBaron B. Colt"). On April 19, the U.S. Senate voted, 62 to 6, to pass the bill.
sources: "Japan Warns U.S. Against Exclusion Act— Hughes Told Grave 'Consequences' Will Follow Approval By Congress; Hanihara's Note Assailed in Senate". *[Baltimore Sun](/wiki/Baltimore_Sun "Baltimore Sun")*. April 12, 1924. p. 1.
"Senate Adopts Immigration Measure, 62—6". *[Baltimore Sun](/wiki/Baltimore_Sun "Baltimore Sun")*. April 19, 1924. p. 1.

content: At 6:00 in the morning, the U.S. state of [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona "Arizona") closed its border with the state of [California](/wiki/California "California"), barring all automobile traffic at the two entry points, [Yuma, Arizona](/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona "Yuma, Arizona") and [Needles, California](/wiki/Needles,_California "Needles, California"). A scandal broke within the U.S. Navy after a radio operator discovered that members of the crew of the battleship [USS *Arizona*](/wiki/USS_Arizona_(BB-39) "USS Arizona (BB-39)") (which would be sunk at Pearl Harbor in 1941) had helped an American [prostitute](/wiki/Prostitution "Prostitution"), [Madeline Blair](/wiki/Madeline_Blair "Madeline Blair"), [stow away](/wiki/Stowaway "Stowaway") when the ship was anchored at New York City. Miss Blair, who had told sailors on [shore leave](/wiki/Shore_leave "Shore leave") that she didn't have enough money to travel to California in hopes of becoming a [Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles "Hollywood, Los Angeles") actress, was found after the ship had passed through the [Panama Canal](/wiki/Panama_Canal "Panama Canal") and was anchored off of the coast of [Panama](/wiki/Panama "Panama") at [Balboa](/wiki/Balboa,_Panama "Balboa, Panama"). The ship's captain instigated the [courts-martial](/wiki/Courts-martial "Courts-martial") of 23 enlisted men. Blair would publish her story in *[The San Francisco Examiner](/wiki/The_San_Francisco_Examiner "The San Francisco Examiner")* in 1928.
sources: "Girl Stowaway Found On U.S. Battleship— Says She is Madeline Blair, Brooklyn, And Boarded Vessel March 12 in Hudson River". *[Baltimore Evening Sun](/wiki/Baltimore_Evening_Sun "Baltimore Evening Sun")*. April 16, 1924. p. 1.

content: The Plaza Publishing Company, which would become [Simon & Schuster](/wiki/Simon_%26_Schuster "Simon & Schuster"), the new publishing company that had been founded on January 2, released *The Cross Word Puzzle Book*, the first book of [crossword puzzles](/wiki/Crossword_puzzle "Crossword puzzle") ever published. Although the crossword had been invented in 1913 and the puzzles were a feature in daily newspapers, the book compiled "50 Brand New Puzzles". content: A group of 700 frustrated drivers from California attempted to break through Arizona's quarantine closure of the border at [Yuma](/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona "Yuma, Arizona"), before being stopped by troops of the Arizona National Guard. content: *[National Barn Dance](/wiki/National_Barn_Dance "National Barn Dance")*, one of the first popular weekly radio shows, was introduced on the Chicago radio station [WLS](/wiki/WLS_(AM) "WLS (AM)"), running from 8 to 12 in the evening central time as an "old time fiddlers program" played by the Hotel Sherman orchestra. As a "[clear-channel](/wiki/Clear-channel_station "Clear-channel station")" broadcaster whose signal could be heard at 870 kHz on AM radio, the WLS program could in much of the North America and was soon licensed to other clear-channel stations. In 1933, *National Barn Chance* would be picked up by the [NBC Red Network](/wiki/NBC_Radio_Network "NBC Radio Network"), before moving to the ABC Radio Network in 1946, and would remain a regular Saturday evening program until 1952.
sources: Carlin, Richard (2013). *Country Music: A Biographical Dictionary*. New York: Routledge. p. 284. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-415-93802-0](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-93802-0 "Special:BookSources/978-0-415-93802-0").

content: The [Ministers and Secretaries Act 1924](/wiki/Ministers_and_Secretaries_Acts "Ministers and Secretaries Acts"), the most definite provision for cabinet departments for the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State"), was passed by the *[Oireachtas](/wiki/Oireachtas "Oireachtas")*, the Irish Parliament, to take effect on June 2. content: The Royal Dutch Airline, [KLM](/wiki/KLM "KLM"), had its first fatal accident when a KLM *[Fokker F.III](/wiki/Fokker_F.III "Fokker F.III")* airplane, carrying a pilot and two passengers, [vanished](/wiki/1924_KLM_Fokker_F.III_disappearance "1924 KLM Fokker F.III disappearance") shortly after takeoff from [Croydon Airport](/wiki/Croydon_Airport "Croydon Airport") in England on a flight to the [Waalhaven](/wiki/Waalhaven "Waalhaven"), a suburb of [Rotterdam](/wiki/Rotterdam "Rotterdam") in the Netherlands. No trace of the plane was found the aircraft had apparently crashed in the [English Channel](/wiki/English_Channel "English Channel").
sources: "Vanished Aeroplane. All Hope Abandoned of Finding Missing Fokker". *Birmingham (England) Evening Despatch*. April 25, 1924. p. 1.

[Voting was held for white residents](/wiki/1924_Southern_Rhodesian_general_election "1924 Southern Rhodesian general election") of the British African colony of [Southern Rhodesia](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia "Southern Rhodesia") (now the [Republic of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Republic_of_Zimbabwe "Republic of Zimbabwe")) for the first [elected colonial legislature](/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Rhodesia "Legislative Assembly of Rhodesia"), the 30-member Legislative Assembly. The [Rhodesia Party](/wiki/Responsible_Government_Association "Responsible Government Association"), led by the Premier, [Sir Charles Coghlan](/wiki/Charles_Coghlan_(politician) "Charles Coghlan (politician)"), won 26 of the seats, while independent candidates won the other four. The [Rhodesia Labour Party](/wiki/Rhodesia_Labour_Party "Rhodesia Labour Party") of Lawrence Keller lost in all 22 constituencies in which it had candidates.

content: An [outbreak of tornadoes](/wiki/April_1924_tornado_outbreak "April 1924 tornado outbreak") killed 111 people across in five states in the southern U.S, with 76 deaths in [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina"), primarily in a storm that swept through [Richland County](/wiki/Richland_County,_South_Carolina "Richland County, South Carolina") [Sumter County](/wiki/Sumter_County,_South_Carolina "Sumter County, South Carolina"). Another 16 died in Georgia and 13 in Alabama.
sources: "95 Dead in Dixie Tornado — Path of Ruin in 6 States 1,000 Miles Long". *Chicago Daily Tribune*. May 1, 1974.

content: [Warren T. McCray](/wiki/Warren_T._McCray "Warren T. McCray") resigned as [Governor](/wiki/Governor_of_Indiana "Governor of Indiana") of the U.S. state of [Indiana](/wiki/Indiana "Indiana") after being convicted in a federal criminal trial for [mail fraud](/wiki/Mail_fraud "Mail fraud") and sentenced to 10 years in prison. McCray was succeeded by Lieutenant Governor [Emmett Forest Branch](/wiki/Emmett_Forest_Branch "Emmett Forest Branch"), to serve out the remaining 8½ months of McCray's term.
sources: "$10,000 Fine; Ten-Year Prison Term for M'Cray — Branch, in Simple Ceremony, Takes office as Thirty-Second Governor of Indiana". *Indianapolis News*. April 30, 1924. p. 1.
